original_title: Sri Lanka’s next step is to get bilateral creditors to restart loan programs: President
original_body_lines: ECONOMYNEXT – Sri Lanka needs to get bilateral creditors to restart suspended loan programs, President Ranil Wickremesinghe said during his budget debate closing speech on Wednesday (13).

“The World Bank, which has strengthened the financial sector with 150 million dollars, has given the country an assurance. The Banks and the financial sector are 100 percent secure,” Wickremesinghe said, emphasizing the importance of the first phase in the debt restructuring process.
“In the same way, the Asian Development Bank and Japan International Cooperation Agency (JICA) provide far more funding for development, with low interest rates and beneficial conditions.”
Since Sri Lanka declared bankruptcy last year, a considerable amount of loan and grant programs by international creditors, like Japan, have been halted. These projects span a variety of sectors.
Wickremesinghe said that foreign investors can now invest in Sri Lankan projects without doubt and fear, as Sri Lanka’s letters of credit are once again “accepted internationally”.
“We can once again expand our market and gain more international acceptance. We have to put in a considerable effort into maximising this opportunity.” (Colombo/Dec14/2023)
